arm_group.description: Older heart failure patients undergoing left ventricular assist device implantation

brief_summary.textblock:
This is an observational study evaluating changes in frailty and associated impairments in
      older heart failure patients receiving left ventricular assist device therapy.

clinical_study.brief_title: Frailty: Prevalence and Response to Left Ventricular Assist Device Therapy in Older Heart Failure Patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  60 years old or older

          -  Scheduled to undergo HeartMate II left ventricular assist device implantation at
             Thomas Jefferson University

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Unable or unwilling to provide informed consent

          -  Unable to complete baseline frailty assessment

study_pop.textblock:
Consecutive heart failure patients 60 years old or older undergoing left ventricular
        assist device implantation.

clinical_study.official_title: Frailty: Prevalence and Response to Left Ventricular Assist Device Therapy in Older Heart Failure Patients

other_outcome.measure: Cognitive function measured by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment

primary_outcome.description: Frailty will be assess based on the domains initially described by Fried and colleagues: weakness, low physical activity, unintentional weight loss, slowness and exhaustion.  Additional frailty measures include the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB), as well as gait speed and hand grip strength as single item measures.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in frailty following left ventricular assist device implantation
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (prior to surgery); 10 days, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months post-operatively

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Skeletal muscle size as measured by ultrasonography
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (prior to surgery); 10 days and 3 months postoperatively

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
